title: Molar Mass of Butane and Calorimetry

content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student performs an experiment to determine the molar mass of butane, <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math>.

(a) To determine the molar mass, the student collects a sample of butane gas over water in a <math alttext="50.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.00</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mL</mtext></math> gas-collection tube, as shown in the following diagram. The student then adjusts the position of the tube so the water level is the same inside and outside the tube. A partial data table for the experiment is also shown.

Initial mass of <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math> container<math alttext="25.012 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.012</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math>Final mass of <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math> container<math alttext="24.911 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24.911</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math>Initial volume of gas<math alttext="0.00 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mtext>mL</mtext></math>Final volume of gas<math alttext="question mark" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>?</mo></math>Atmospheric pressure<math alttext="0.970 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.970</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>atm</mtext></math>Temperature<math alttext="21.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>

(i) What should the student record for the volume of the gas collected, in <math alttext="milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mL</mtext></math>?<math alttext="blank" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi></math>

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student performs an experiment to determine the molar mass of butane, <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math>.

(a) To determine the molar mass, the student collects a sample of butane gas over water in a <math alttext="50.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.00</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mL</mtext></math> gas-collection tube, as shown in the following diagram. The student then adjusts the position of the tube so the water level is the same inside and outside the tube. A partial data table for the experiment is also shown.

Initial mass of <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math> container<math alttext="25.012 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.012</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math>Final mass of <math alttext="C 4 H 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math> container<math alttext="24.911 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24.911</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math>Initial volume of gas<math alttext="0.00 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mtext>mL</mtext></math>Final volume of gas<math alttext="question mark" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>?</mo></math>Atmospheric pressure<math alttext="0.970 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.970</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>atm</mtext></math>Temperature<math alttext="21.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>

(i) What should the student record for the volume of the gas collected, in <math alttext="milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mL</mtext></math>?<math alttext="blank" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi></math>

(ii) Given that the vapor pressure of water at <math alttext="21.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> is <math alttext="0.0246 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0246</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math>, calculate the partial pressure, in atmospheres, of butane collected. Assume that the total pressure in the gas-collection tube is equal to the atmospheric pressure in the laboratory.
(iii) Calculate the number of moles of butane gas in the gas-collection tube.

(b) The student then incorrectly determines the molar mass of butane by dividing the initial mass of the container with butane (<math alttext="25.012 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.012</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math>) by the number of moles of butane calculated in part (a)(iii). Assuming that the number of moles calculated in part (a)(iii) is accurate, describe how to correct the student’s calculation.

Butane undergoes combustion according to the following balanced equation.
<math alttext="C 4 H 10, gas plus thirteen halves O 2, gas, reacts to produce, 4 C O 2, gas plus 5 H 2 O, gas, where delta H naught equals negative 2660 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>13</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2660</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>
(c) Which species undergoes reduction in the combustion reaction? Justify your answer with oxidation numbers.
(d) Determine the sign of the entropy change for the reaction. Use particle reasoning to justify your answer.

<math alttext="C 4 H 10, gas plus thirteen halves O 2, gas, reacts to produce, 4 C O 2, gas plus 5 H 2 O, gas, where delta H naught equals negative 2660 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>13</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2660</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>
(e) A student combusts <math alttext="9.29 times 10 to the negative 4 power mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9.29</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mol</mtext></math> of butane as shown in the preceding equation in a calorimeter containing <math alttext="100.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.0</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math> of water.

(i) Calculate the heat, in <math alttext="joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>J</mtext></math>, released during the combustion of butane.

(ii) Calculate the temperature change of the water in the calorimeter. (Assume that the calorimeter is perfectly insulated and all the heat released by the combustion of butane is transferred to the <math alttext="100.0 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> sample of water.) The specific heat capacity of water is <math alttext="4.18 joules per gram degree Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.18</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>J/(g·°C)</mtext></math>.

The student repeats the calorimetry experiment under the same conditions, replacing the butane with an equimolar amount of propane. The following reaction occurs.
<math alttext="C 3 H 8, gas, plus 5 O 2, gas, reacts to produce, 3 C O 2, gas plus 4 H 2 O, gas, where delta H naught equals negative 2040 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>8</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2040</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>
(f) Predict whether the change in temperature observed during the combustion would be greater than, less than, or equal to the change in part (e)(ii). Justify your answer.

(g) The Lewis diagrams for butane and propane are shown above. Both compounds exhibit London dispersion attractive forces. Explain why the London dispersion forces between molecules of butane are stronger than those between molecules of propane.

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
